intro: Nigella arvensis var. intermedia, commonly known as the intermediate cumin, is a herbaceous annual plant native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, yellowish-green flowers. The plant produces oval, elongated seeds that are often used in traditional medicine and as a spice. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun, making it a common weed in agricultural fields. Its botanical features include alternate leaves with a hairy texture and a distinct, aromatic scent.
